question: Question_B_05
statement:
In the Chernobyl reactor explosion, which occurred on April 26, 1986,
substantial amounts of the isotope strontium-90 (\textsuperscript{90}Sr)
contaminated the area around the nuclear plant. \textsuperscript{90}Sr
decays at a rate proportional to its quantity. \textsuperscript{90}Sr
has a half-life of 29 years; that is, it takes 29 years for a quantity
of \textsuperscript{90}Sr to decrease by half. What is the proportion of
\textsuperscript{90}Sr originally released which remains on April 26,
2012?
sols:
As stated in the second hint, we will first use the information about
half-life to solve for the rate of decay, or \emph{k} in the equation:

\[\displaystyle y(t) = Ce^{kt}\]

If $y(t)$ is the percentage remaining after $t$ years, we know that
$50\%$ of \textsuperscript{90}Sr remains after 29 years. At \emph{t = 0}
the amount is 100 percent, hence choose \emph{C = 100}. Plugging this
into the formula gives:

\[\displaystyle 50 = 100e^{k29}\]

Solving for $k$, we get

$\ln(\frac12) = 29k$

$\displaystyle k = \ln(1/2)/29$

Plugging this back into our formula for $y(t)$, we can now solve for the
percentage remaining on April 26, 2012, when $t = 26$.

\[\displaystyle y(t) = 100e^{(\ln(1/2)/29)*26}\]

Simplifying will give:

\[y(t) = 100*(\frac12)^{26/29}\]

or 53\% remaining.
hints:
Recall that radioactive decay is an example of exponential decay,
described by the formula $\displaystyle y(t) = Ce^{kt}$, where $y(t)$ is
the percentage of material left after \emph{t} years, and \emph{C} is
the initial amount.

Before you can calculate the current amount remaining, you will have to
use the information about half-life to find \emph{k}.

With a half life of 29 year, expect more than 50\% of the material to be
remaining at 26 years.
